Award.AwardTitle: ChemMine Tools: an Open Source Framework for Chemical Genomics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California, Riverside is awarded a grant to develop ChemMineTools, an environment to efficiently analyze and model large sets of small molecules along with their bioactivity data. It will provide unrestricted access to a scalable set of open source tools that integrates novel and existing algorithm. To maximize its utility spectrum for experimental and computational scientists, the analysis modules will be available from the powerful R environment, as well as an intuitive-to-use web interface. The specific objectives of this project are: (1) The development and implementation of accelerated compound search and clustering algorithms that scale to today's large databases with millions entries. This will focus on the expansion of the ultrafast EI-Search and EI-Clustering algorithms by embedding and indexing (EI). These multipurpose algorithms will be adopted to advanced similarity measures that can currently not be used for processing large databases due their insufficient speed performance. (2) The R package ChemMine R Tools will be developed. It will offer access to advanced clustering, machine learning and visualization functionalities along with interactive visualization tools. (3) User-friendly access to all analysis and visualization tools will be provided by the ChemMine Web Tools interface. (4) An educational outreach program will be offered to provide extensive training opportunities and to integrate underrepresented groups into this project.

By integrating novel and existing analysis routines in an efficient data mining environment, the project will disseminate and transform multidisciplinary concepts of powerful chemical approaches in modern biology. Moreover, it will encourage young scientists to incorporate cheminformatics strategies into their daily research. Substantial educational resources for interdisciplinary training at the intersect of computational biology and cheminformatics will be provided by this project. Workshops will be offered to scientists, postdoctoral researchers, graduate, undergraduate, high school and other K-12 students. Members of underrepresented groups will participate in all aspects of this project. Extensive online workshop and software manuals will be provided to maximize the educational outreach of the activities. Further information about this project may be found at its website: http://cmtools.ucr.edu.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed the scientific data analysis environment ChemMine Tools, a powerful software toolbox for analyzing small molecules and high-throughput screening data. These modeling utilities are important for agricultural chemistry and drug discovery where researchers are trying to develop more potent bioactive chemicals for controlling pathogens, and curing diseases in plants, animals and humans. In addition, ChemMine Tools enables basic research in chemical genomics. In this field small molecules are used as probes to study how biological systems function mechanistically. ChemMine Tools provides researchers and the general public with unrestricted access to a scalable open source software environment by integrating novel and existing algorithms for the analysis of small molecule and screening data with functionalities reaching far beyond those available previously. To maximize its utility for experimental and computational scientists, the analysis modules have been developed for the powerful statistical data analysis environment R, as well as an intuitive-to-use web interface. More specifically, ChemMine Tools provides utilities for analyzing large numbers of molecules, physicochemical/structural property predictions, structural similarity searching, classification and clustering of compound libraries and screening results with a wide spectrum of algorithms. For instance, the fmcsR algorithm has been developed as part of this project. It is the first mismatch tolerant maximum common substructure search tool in the field. In our comparisons with related structure similarity search tools, fmcsR showed the best virtual screening (VS) performance for predicting novel bioactive small molecules. This novel functionality is useful for accelerating the discovery of novel small molecules relevant for agricultural, environmental or human health-related applications.  

The development of the resources provided by ChemMine Tools will have a significant impact on the broader field of small molecule discovery by enabling analyses of large compound data set with methods that could not be used before due to performance limitations of many algorithms. By integrating novel and existing analysis routines in an efficient data mining environment, the project also contributes to the dissemination and transformation of multidisciplinary concepts of powerful chemical approaches in modern biology. Moreover, it encourages young scientists to incorporate cheminformatics strategies into their daily research. Substantial educational resources for interdisciplinary training at the intersect of computational biology and cheminformatics have been provided by this project. This included annual 5-day large-scale data analysis workshops taught by the personnel of this project. Each event has been attended by 75-95 participants from academia and industry from many different locations in the US. This integrated software development and outreach program has greatly contributed to the success of the project.

 


Last Modified: 07/30/2015
Modified by: Thomas Girke
